The European Union Emissions Trading System (ETS) was implemented in 2005. ETS prices remained low for a long time but started to rise in 2017. The ETS allowance prices surged in 2021, reaching almost €100 in February 2022. However, prices dropped below €60 in early March after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

Our contribution to the literature on carbon pricing is twofold. First, we propose a new EU Climate Change News Index (ECCNI) that tracks the ongoing discussion in the EU about climate change using global media sources. Although some studies have incorporated news information into the forecasting of ETS prices (Ye and Xue, 2021; Zhang and Xia, 2022), no meaningful feature has been created that captures the media's climate policy-related discussions. We apply term frequency-inverse document frequency (TF-IDF) feature extraction to the GDELT news database to measure the frequency of climate change-related keywords in the news associated with the EU. The TF-IDF features help to quantify the intensity of the discussion about climate change in the EU and to incorporate policy context in the analysis of carbon prices.

Second, we apply the news index to predict the next day's ETS allowance price returns. We test the forecast accuracy of the ECCNI against a set of control variables taken from the literature. Our results suggest that the occurrence of climate change-related keywords in the most reliable news sites improves the forecasts of the ETS prices.

Several quantitative methods have been developed in academic literature to forecast carbon prices. These papers can be categorized into two groups: (1) forecasting based on time-series data using carbon price only, and (2) extending with economic and energy data. The carbon price-only methods mostly include ARIMA models, which can only capture linear relationships (Zhu and Chevallier, 2017). Therefore, more advanced frameworks have been applied to carbon prices, such as GARCH models (Arouri et al., 2012; Benschop and López-Cabrer, 2014; Byun and Cho, 2013) and VAR models (Arouri et al., 2012).

However, carbon price-only methods do not incorporate all available information in the market. Various studies have used economic and energy-related variables to proxy the demand for CO2 allowances (Arouri et al., 2012; Guðbrandsdóttir and Haraldsson, 2011; Zhao et al., 2018). Recently, alternative predictors, such as news data through natural language processing (NLP), have been used to forecast ETS prices (Ye and Xue, 2021; Zhang and Xia, 2022). However, they only included the headlines and titles of online news from limited sources and could only examine carbon prices with a weekly frequency.

To shed more light on the impact of news on daily ETS prices, we create features by applying the TF-IDF method to the GDELT news dataset. TF-IDF has been widely used to improve the forecast accuracy of stock prices (Coyne et al., 2017; Lubis et al., 2021; Mittermayer, 2004; Nikfarjam et al., 2010).

Data
The main contribution of this study is the conversion of online news articles to meaningful variables that enhances our understanding of ETS. We use the GDELT database, a free open platform covering global news from numerous countries in over 100 languages with daily frequency. The database includes information on actors, locations, organizations, themes, and sources of the news items (Leetaru and Schrodt, 2013). GDELT has been used in various studies that apply NLP to extract alternative information from the news (Alamro et al., 2019; Galla and Burke, 2018; Guidolin and Pedio, 2021).

We take the daily futures closing prices of the European Union Allowance (EUA) (€/ton) as the dependent variable since it is the underlying carbon price of ETS. Besides news data, we include the most fundamental drivers of ETS prices (Ye and Xue, 2021) in our analysis to serve as control variables. The data was collected from January 2, 2018, until November 30.
